questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following structures lack labile cells?
questions.explanation:
114 
Sold by @itachibot The liver contains stable cells, not labile cells. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: • Labile tissues • Stable tissues • Permanent tissues Labile cells refer to continuously proliferating cells that are lost and replaced by the maturation 
of stem cells and the proliferation of these mature cells. Tissues containing these cells can readily 
regenerate after an injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved. Some examples of labile cells include: • Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow • Majority of surface epithelia - • Stratified squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity, vagina, and cervix • Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs (salivary glands, biliary tract) • Columnar epithelium of the GIT, uterus, and fallopian tubes • Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following tissues does not consist of stable cells?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac muscle does not contain stable cells. It contains permanent cells which are terminally 
differentiated and non-proliferative. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: • Labile tissues • Stable tissues • Permanent tissues Stable cells are quiescent (in the G0 stage of the cell cycle) and have only minimal proliferative 
activity in their normal state. However, they can divide in response to injury or loss of tissue 
mass. They include the following: • Parenchyma of solid tissues (liver, kidney, and pancreas) • Endothelial cells • Fibroblasts • Smooth muscle cells

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following does not contain permanent cells?
questions.explanation:
115 
Sold by @itachibot Smooth muscle does not contain permanent cells. It consists of stable cells that are capable of 
dividing in response to injury or loss of tissue mass. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: • Labile tissues • Stable tissues • Permanent tissues Permanent cells are those which are considered to be terminally differentiated and 
non-proliferative in postnatal life. In permanent tissues, the repair is typically dominated by scar 
formation. These cells include: • Neurons • Cardiac muscle • Skeletal muscle - contains satellite cells attached to the endomysial sheath which have some 
regenerative capacity

questions.question: Question 4: Oval cells are seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Oval cells refer to stem cells in the liver. They are located in the canals of Hering. Regeneration of the liver occurs by two major mechanisms: • Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes - occurs following partial hepatectomy (resection of up to 
90% of the liver can be corrected by this mechanism) • Repopulation from progenitor cells (oval cells) - occurs following chronic liver injury or 
inflammation

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is a false statement regarding TGF- ?

options.a: It increases the synthesis of collagen
options.b: It increases the degradation of the extracellular matrix
options.c: It is involved in the development of fibrosis in solid organs

questions.explanation:
TGF- (transforming growth factor- ) decreases the degradation of the extracellular matrix by 
inhibiting metalloproteinases. It is produced by most cells in granulation tissue, including alternatively activated macrophages. The functions of TGF- include: • Stimulates fibroblast migration and proliferation • Increases synthesis of collagen and fibronectin (connective tissue proteins) • Decreased degradation of ECM by inhibiting metalloproteinases • Involved in scar formation after injury • Development of fibrosis in lung, liver, and kidneys following chronic inflammation • Anti-inflammatory action by inhibiting lymphocyte proliferation and activity 116 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: All of the following delay healing except:
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoid excess results in delayed healing, not glucocorticoid deficiency. Various factors affect wound healing including mechanical factors (pressure and torsion and site 
of injury) and location and extent of the injury. Vitamin C helps in the activation of prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases which help in the hydroxylation 
of procollagen. As inadequately hydroxylated procollagen is vulnerable to enzymatic degradation, 
vitamin C plays an essential role in wound healing.

questions.question:

questions.question:
Question 8: A 38-year-old man underwent excision of a lipoma. The swelling had been excised with a 
clear linear incision and was sutured cleanly. In this wound, when would you expect peak 
neovascularization?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a clean surgical incision that is sutured is an example of healing 
by primary intention. In this type of healing, neovascularization reaches its peak by day 5, as 
granulation tissue fills the incisional space. These new vessels are leaky, allowing the passage of plasma proteins and fluid into the 
extravascular space. Hence, new granulation tissue is often edematous.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the 
abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen 
seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional 
matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin. It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen. This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, 
abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a 
combination of regeneration and scarring. 118 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair may give rise to which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair leads to the formation of 
hypertrophic scar. When this scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound, it is 
known as a keloid. Collagen plays a role in the normal adherence of tissue edges at the site of injury. Contraction in 
the size of a wound is an important part of the normal healing process. An exaggeration of this 
process gives rise to contractures. They are particularly prone to develop on the palms, soles, 
anterior thorax and are commonly seen after serious burns. Inadequate formation of granulation tissue or formation of a scar leads to wound dehiscence and 
ulceration. The following image shows a hypertrophic scar.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 24-year-old man comes with the following findings. He says that he cut himself while 
shaving 3 months back. What is the diagnosis? 112 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The history of a shaving cut and the image showing a large area of scar tissue are suggestive of a 
keloid. A keloid refers to excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site with growth of the scar 
tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound. It does not regress. Option A: Exuberant granulation or proud flesh refers to the protrusion of excessive amounts of 
granulation tissue above the level of the surrounding skin. This blocks re-epithelialization. Option B: The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen may give rise to a raised scar known 
as a hypertrophic scar. However, it remains within the boundaries of the original scar. Option D: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, vascular tumor. 119 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presented to the OPD with the following finding on her finger. She says that she cut 
her finger while chopping vegetables 2 weeks ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and clinical findings are suggestive of exuberant granulation. It is a deviation in wound healing where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above 
the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization. It is also known as proud flesh.

questions.question:
Question 13: In postoperative patients, what is the strength of the incision site in comparison with normal 
skin following suture removal at the end of 1 week?

options.a: It is a non-inflammatory edema or effusion
options.b: It is a protein-poor and cell-poor fluid
options.c: It has a specific gravity of less than 1.012
options.d: It is caused by increased vascular permeability

questions.explanation:
When sutures are removed, usually at 1 week, the wound strength is approximately 10% of that of 
normal skin. This increases rapidly over the next 4 weeks. Wound strength reaches approximately 70 to 80% of 
normal by 3 months. Beyond this, there is not much improvement. 120 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Hemodynamics and Hemostasis
